Research Data Management & Open Data

## Open Science in the research process
![](img/Open_Science_in_research_process.jpg){width=750px}
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
::: footer get all material here: [https://osf.io/zjrhu/](https://osf.io/zjrhu/) ::: ##

Why open data?

![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Why open data?
::: columns ::: {.column width="70%"} - *1. Nullius in verba* - take nobody's word for it - Motto of the oldest scientific society (Royal Society, founded 1660) - Science is not built upon blind trust, but on verifiability. - „Organized skepticism“ (Merton, 1947) ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](img/Nullius_in_verba.jpg){width=300px} ::: ::: ::: {.smallest} Only when raw data (and other research material) are shared organized skepticism can be enacted, and science can really be self-correcting. Open data is one part of good scientific practice. :::
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Why open data? - *2. Efficiency and Inclusiveness* - Speedy responses in outbreaks; share rare and hard-to-collect data
![](img/Efficiency_and_Inclusiveness.jpg){ width=800px}
::: {.smallest} The covid-19 pandemic has shown how fast scientific progress can be when we share our data and knowledge freely, and that free knowledge is a moral imperative. :::
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Why open data? - *3. Public money = public good*
![](img/Public_money.jpg){ width=600px}
::: footer [https://publiccode.eu/en/](https://publiccode.eu/en/) ::: ::: {.smallest} Publicly funded research data does not belong to the researcher who collected it. S/he has the right of primary usage, but after that the data should be considered a public good (of course respecting privacy rights and applicable copyrights). :::
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Why open data?
::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} - *4. Data persistence* - never lose data due to a crashed hard disk drive ::: ::: {.column width="40%"}
![](img/Data_persistence.jpg){width=200px}
::: ::: ::: {.smallest} A publicly funded repository is the right place for long term storage of research data – not your private USB stick, your personal university website (that vanishes after you change affiliation), or the journal’s online supplemental material that hides the data behind a paywall. :::
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Why open data? - *5. More and more funders and journals demand it.*
![](img/Top_Guidelines.jpg){width=750px}
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}

Balancing values:
Three fields of tension with
(human subject) data

![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
##
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}



![](img/Balancing_values.jpg){width=750px}
## Balancing values: Three fields of
tension with human subject data
![](img/Balancing_values_2.jpg){width=700px}
- Privacy rights > openness; but also: „legitimate interest“ of research - Ask participants for a broad consent of open reuse - Restrict access with „scientific use files“; publish aggregated data (e.g., ratings of videos) without the primary data (videos) - Sharing something > sharing nothing - As open as possible, as restricted as necessary
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Balancing values: Three fields of
tension with human subject data
![](img/Balancing_values_3.jpg){width=700px}
- Right of first usage, possibility of embargo - At the end of the day (resp., the embargo), all data are as open as possible - Incentivize data sharing
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
##
![](img/Story_1.jpg){width=750px}
##
![](img/Story_2.jpg){width=750px}
## Balancing values: Three fields of
tension with human subject data
![](img/Balancing_values_4.jpg){width=700px}
- Primary focus: openness and transparency. Correcting errors is painful, but a necessary condition for doing science - Data providers should be informed if their data are going to be reused or reanalyzed ➙ allows to prepare a reaction
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
## Balancing values: Three fields of
tension with human subject data
![](img/Balancing_values_4.jpg){width=700px}
- Problematic asymmetry: - Data provided ➙ often errors get detected - No data provided ➙ no errors are detected (because not possible). Default assumption: „Everything is OK. Perfect paper, because no errors are spotted!“ - Making oneself vulnerable is good for science, and should also be good for reputation! - Change default assumption? „No data ➙ Probably erroneous analysis.“
![](img/OSC_LMU_Open_Science_Center.jpg){width=200px}
